data.title: What to Do With 2 Days In Dublin, Ireland
data.meta_description: What to do if you've got 24 hours or 2 days in Dublin. Itinerary ideas, what to do (& what to skip), where to eat in Dublin, & much more!
data.text:
Do you believe in love at first sight??

In life in general, I don‚Äôt really. But in travel, that‚Äôs a different story. There are places that just grab you by the throat and seep into your pores to become a part of you.

It doesn‚Äôt really have anything to do with the amount of time you spend there‚Ä¶could be a day, a week, or a month. But once you leave, it has carved out a little permanent residence in your heart and the back of your mind.

Check out ‚ÄúCapital Cities‚Äù, a Beautiful & Unique Travel Coffee Book Collaboration!

Ireland overall did that for me, and Dublin was a big part of that. My visits to this gorgeous city full of craic (fun, energy, liveliness) have been super short each time, but I was hooked and could go back time after time.

And you‚Äôd be shocked how much you can see and do in only a day or two here‚ÄîDublin is a perfect day or weekend trip!

Other awesome Irish roadtrip tips to plan your own!

The Medieval Charms of Kilkenny

A Road Trip Along Ireland‚Äôs Southern Coast: Things To Do In County Cork & Waterford

Review of Ardmore‚Äôs Gorgeous Cliff House Hotel: A Must-Stay

Why The Charming Village of Ardmore Is a Must-Visit + the Famous Cliff Walk

Driving the Stunning Beara Peninsula

Exploring Ireland‚Äôs Beautiful Dingle Peninsula (& 10+ Hidden Gems)

What to Expect at the Cliffs of Moher (& the Best Alternative Options)

Why You Should Consider Loop Head Instead of Cliffs of Moher

Duchess For A Day: A Luxury Stay At Dromoland Castle (Co. Clare) + Afternoon Tea

Clonmacnoise Monastery, Ireland: An Ireland Roadtrip Must-See

24 Hours On Inis Mor, In Ireland‚Äôs Aran Islands (including exploring D√∫n Aonghasa)

What to Do in Ireland‚Äôs Boyne Valley Region & Slane Village

Whiskey, History, & Rock ‚Äòn‚Äô Roll at Ireland‚Äôs Slane Distillery & Castle

‚ÄòKeeving It Real‚Äô: Cider Making in Ireland‚Äôs Boyne Valley

Boyne Valley Cheese: Visiting a Creamery in Slane, Ireland

Tips For Renting A Car & Driving In Ireland

The Perfect 7-Day Ireland Roadtrip Itinerary: Hidden Gems

A little about Dublin

Dublin is a fascinating city with over a millennium of history and multiple major cultural groups conquering as well as melding together. Dublin was founded by Danish Vikings in 841. The Vikings slowly converted to Christianity, and the Irishmen and Vikings continued to battle over the years.

The Normans entered the picture in the late 1100s and a Norman lord and his army crushed both the Vikings and the native Irish. The English king were worried that they were getting too powerful, so got involved and subsequent centuries were under British rule.

In more recent memory, Ireland is known for a couple of things, including the potato famine in the 1840s that led 2 million people to flee the country and 1 million to starve to death. Dublin was the focal point of the Easter Uprising in 1916, where the Irish pushed back against British rule and tried to create an independent republic.

It wasn‚Äôt successful at the time, and was followed by years of civil war and fighting, but today the Republic of Ireland is its own independent country.

Dublin is a city of energy and youth, with a history of poets and rebels. It wears its centuries well, and is SO much fun. The people are welcoming and interesting, and you‚Äôll absolutely love it.

You might also like: A Guide to Finding the Right Flight Every Time

Where to stay in Dublin

Our first trip, we stayed at Buswells Hotel (check avails on Booking.com too), which has a great location, was very comfortable, and a good price for central Dublin.

On the splurge end, a great option is The Merrion (see also on TripAdvisor), which is absolutely gorgeous and will make you feel like a queen (my friend Andrea raved about it).

Both hotels are located very centrally in St. Stephen‚Äôs Green, which is a lovely area and easily walkable to all sorts of sights, restaurants, nightlife, and more.

My tips for making the most of your visit

Here are a few things to think about overall. I‚Äôll share specific itinerary thoughts below.

It goes without saying, but get an early start to the day. Dublin shines in the morning!

Eat!! Fish & chips, steak & Guinness pie, scones, boxty, colcannon, beer‚Ä¶stop and grab a snack every chance you get!

Walk everywhere. So much of Dublin is just getting a feel for the city, and in our experience it was a super walkable city. From Temple Bar to O‚ÄôConnell Street to St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral and all the places between, exploring the nooks and crannies of the city was my favorite part.

Only do tours like Guinness or Jameson if you‚Äôre dying to. They‚Äôre fun and if you‚Äôre a fan, worth it (also a good way to avoid bad weather for a bit). Consider other smaller ones like Teeling, or even taking a day trip out to a working distillery like Slane.

Find a whiskey shop that offers a tasting or samples, and take them up on it. My dad and I loved that, and the shop sold airplane-size bottles of a lot of the Irish whiskeys (including largely unknown ones) so I grabbed a few as a gift for one of my co-workers.

If you‚Äôre a museum die-hard (I am emphatically NOT), there are a couple of must-sees in Dublin (including the Book of Kells), so do some research on that.

You might also like: 10 Thing You Have To Do Before Every Trip

2 days in Dublin: structuring your itinerary

Get your walking shoes on, because you‚Äôre going to be covering some ground! Dublin is a super walkable city, and the main sights and areas you‚Äôll want to visit are in a fairly compact area. This helps if you only have one or two days in Dublin.

If you have 1 day in Dublin:

In my opinion this is a walking day with lots of brief stops rather than structured ‚Äúvisits‚Äù. That‚Äôs more my style anyway, but is well suited to Dublin.

You can easily hit the highlights with a day‚Äîplaces like Christ Church Cathedral and St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral, walking up and down the river, Temple Bar area, Trinity College, St. Stephen‚Äôs Green, O‚ÄôConnell Street, and more.

Based on your interests, if you want to do something that takes a bit longer, I‚Äôd go with the Book of Kells and library at Trinity College. A couple other top picks for a longer tour would be Kilmainham Gaol or getting a walking tour at Trinity College.

If you really want to visit either Guinness or Jameson, I‚Äôd recommend choosing one or the other vs. both if you only have one day (or try out Teeling for a smaller, more intimate overview of whiskey distilling).

If you have 2 days in Dublin:

You can add on a second distillery/brewery visit if you want.

With an extra day, you can slow things down and spend a bit more time enjoying each place you visit. Also, it gives you more of a buffer if the weather isn‚Äôt cooperating (so if it‚Äôs rainy, you may get a second chance to see things).

Look for a place you could experience traditional pub music in the evening of your first day.

You might also like: How to Choose the Best Hotel or Rental Every Time

Where to stay in Dublin

The one time I stayed overnight in Dublin, we stayed at Buswells Hotel and were quite happy with it (though it was a number of years ago). It was clean, good value and great location.

You might also like: My Favorite Cross-Body Purse for Travel

What to do with 2 days in Dublin

Here is a long list (in no particular order) of sights to see, places to walk by, and more!

Walk up and down the River Liffey

While you‚Äôll definitely have some specific things you want to see, Dublin is a perfect city for just wandering around, stopping in at shops, taking pictures of the bright colors and (if you get super lucky) enjoying a bright blue sky.

Dublin sits on the River Liffey, so there are tons of bridges with different history and architectural styles. Below I show one famous bridge (Ha‚ÄôPenny) and my personal favorite one (Grattan).

Beyond that, if you have time try to get over and see the Samuel Beckett Bridge. It‚Äôs designed so it looks like a Celtic harp (the national symbol of Ireland). I haven‚Äôt had a chance to see it but it‚Äôs supposed to be cool.

You might also like: The Only Carry-On Suitcase You‚Äôll Need

I‚Äôm going to talk about Ha‚ÄôPenny, the most famous bridge in Dublin, but first *this one* is actually my favorite bridge. This is Grattan Bridge, originally built in 1676. What I love so much about this bridge is that I‚Äôm charmed by the little things‚Äîdecorative touches on lampposts like these seahorses this fun sea green color.

Even though it‚Äôs a driving bridge, it has wide, prettily-landscaped paths for pedestrians and some seating. It‚Äôs right in the thick of things, so make sure to get across it at some point on your wanderings!

You might also like: 20+ Tips to Survive (& Thrive) on a Long Flight

Back in old-timey times, the only way to get across the Liffey was by a terrifying-sounding, overcrowded, and often doomed ferry that slogged back and forth.

Then in 1816 this pretty cast iron bridge opened to anyone who could pay a ha‚Äôpenny (a half penny, what the ferry cost), and made the ferry redundant. The colloquially-called Ha‚ÄôPenny Bridge remained the only pedestrian bridge in Dublin for almost two centuries.

I wouldn‚Äôt go out of your way to see it, but it‚Äôs super central and easy to catch in the course of your wanderings‚Ä¶on one side you‚Äôve got O‚ÄôConnell Street and on the other Temple Bar, so a walk across isn‚Äôt a hardship.

Pro tip: on the north side of Ha‚ÄôPenny, swing by The Winding Stair bookshop, one of the oldest independent bookshops in Dublin. It‚Äôs charming and worth a few minutes. I got a copy of Harry Potter in Gaelic that I love.

Meander through Trinity College

This never gets old, and on a nice day it‚Äôs one of my favorite places in Dublin‚Äîsimply BEAUTIFUL! Founded in 1592, this college is one of the centers of how the modern literary world (in the West) developed‚Ä¶authors like Jonathan Swift, Oscar Wilde, Bram Stoker, Samuel Beckett, and others trace their roots here.

The college is home to the Book of Kells as well as a stunning library that I still haven‚Äôt seen and am dying to. The Book of Kells is a beautifully-decorated vellum copy of the four gospels in Latin from around 800 AD. It‚Äôs illustrated with vivid colors and pictures, and the best surviving example of Celtic art.

You might also like: My Fave Korean Face Sunscreens & Moisturizers for Travel

I‚Äôve only hung out in this open square, and taken about a billion pics, but there‚Äôs a lot more you can do here if you have the time and inclination. Students lead walking tours of the campus for those interested (I think it costs ‚Ç¨10, but that may have changed).

In particular, consider visiting the library and Book of Kells. Visits are self-guided, with displays to help you better understand the history.

There aren‚Äôt reservations, so in the summer months there can be a pretty decent line so make sure to plan for extra time. Check the official website to make sure it‚Äôs open and on display (sometimes it‚Äôs not), and learn more about costs and opening times.

You might also like: The Best Travel Pillow for Different Types of Sleepers

St. Stephen‚Äôs Green

This serene, beautiful public park dates back to Victorian times. It has tons of walking paths, a duck pond, lots of statues‚Ä¶spend a half hour meandering through the paths and stepping away from the city‚Äôs bustle. Unless it‚Äôs pouring, of course!

You might also like: 11 of My Best Tips for ANY Trip

St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral

Of course you can‚Äôt spend even 1 or 2 days in Dublin without a trip to St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral. Founded on the spot where it‚Äôs believed St. Patrick baptized the first Irish believers into Christianity, it‚Äôs been a part of Dublin life for over 800 years.

It‚Äôs a great example of medieval architecture, dating back to the early 13th century, though the first church on this spot was built in the 5th century. I loved that there weren‚Äôt tons of people milling around so I could get beautiful pictures, with the fountain and bright flowers popping against the lines of the cathedral.

I haven‚Äôt been inside (I‚Äôm not super into the inside of cathedrals), but there‚Äôs lots to see as well as choir performances, events, and more. Check the official website for hours and more details.

You might also like: Travel FAQ: How to Pay for Things Overseas & Other Travel Money Tips

Christ Church Cathedral

So while St. Patrick‚Äôs is really cool, I think that Christ Church Cathedral is even cooler. This style of architecture is one I particularly love‚Ä¶look at the top of that tower, those little jaggedy edges (crenelations?).

It‚Äôs Dublin‚Äôs oldest building, dating all the way back to 1030 AD (though initially established by Norsemen as a Viking church and not brought into the Irish church until 1152). Although to be fair, the original structure was wooden and burned down in the Norman invasion, so this stone structure was built in 1171.

You might also like: 13 Cool Souvenir Ideas To Pick Up While Traveling

Enjoy the details and whimsy

As I mentioned at the outset, a lot of the things to ‚Äúsee‚Äù in Dublin are all about wandering the city. Yes, there are a few historic sites that are critical, but Dublin is all about VIBE.

Rather like Lisbon, some of my favorite things about Dublin are just the details‚Ä¶I‚Äôm obsessed with the different shapes and sizes and styles of buildings, the bright colors, the quirky little details that beg you to notice them.

You might also like: My Trip Planning Process: Inspiration>Research>Reality

Don‚Äôt forget to look up‚Ä¶there are so many fun details above you. And I love all the colorful doors of Dublin.

See how different all these buildings are?? But they all mesh together so well. I AM CHARMED.

You might also like: A Travel Bucket List for Your 30s

O‚ÄôConnell Street & the General Post Office

From a more modern historic standpoint, one can‚Äôt-miss is O‚ÄôConnell Square and the General Post Office. In addition to it being a beautiful building and the last great Georgian building constructed here, the General Post Office was the headquarters for the uprising‚Äôs leaders during the Easter Rising of 1916.

It was damaged quite a bit during and you can still see bullet holes in some of the columns. I also loved the Spire of Dublin, it was super fun to photograph. With only one day in Dublin, O‚ÄôConnell Street may or may not make the cut based on your level of interest, but if you have two days in Dublin I (personally) think it‚Äôs a must.

You might also like: 10 Places I‚Äôm Dying to Visit in 2020

Walk around Temple Bar

I never spend much time in the Temple Bar area, but you definitely have to do at least a stroll through it. Named after a famous bar there of the same name (make sure to swing by!), this is synonymous with tourist antics in Dublin.

It‚Äôs not as crazy during the day, but at night transforms into drunken tourist (and hen/stag party) chaos. Not for me, but for many people it‚Äôs a must in Dublin. Just don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre getting the ‚Äúauthentic Irish pub‚Äù experience here.

You might also like: My All-Time Favorite Bra for Travel

Swing by and say hi to Molly Malone

One of the most recognizable symbols of Dublin, you can‚Äôt visit without stopping by to say hi to the statue of Molly Malone. A fishmonger and working girl, she died of cholera in one of the many epidemics that swept Dublin regularly, and was later immortalized in song. Her statue is affectionately called ‚ÄúThe Tart with the Cart‚Äù, and is now located on Suffolk Street.

Snap a quick pic, but I beg of you, don‚Äôt be one of those MANY tourists who grab her boob for a photo op‚Ä¶it‚Äôs not a good look, guys. And I wouldn‚Äôt go out of your way to hit this unless it‚Äôs on your route.

You might also like: How To Plan A Trip: Important Questions To Guide You

Tour Guinness Storehouse

So Guinness is definitely a different experience from Jameson (more on that below). It‚Äôs a self-guided tour, and is a little‚Ä¶like Disneyland? That‚Äôs not a bad thing, just quite the sensory overload and it‚Äôs absolutely massive.

This site has been the home to Guinness since 1759 (when their founder signed a 9,000 year lease‚Ä¶dude did not have commitment issues). It‚Äôs now a seven-story experience dedicated to the history of the making of Guinness.

I bought my ticket ahead of time (official website here) and queued for my tour time. I sped through it‚Äîboth because I‚Äôm fairly impatient, but also because I work in the alcohol industry and at a certain point, you can only learn about barley, distillation, etc. so many times üôÇ

I did buy a couple souvenirs, and then made my way up to the Gravity Bar on the 7th floor for my free pint and the view. The view is great but it was crowded and so not really my vibe, but glad I stopped in.

Read my full post about visiting Guinness Storehouse!

You might also like: The 10 Best Books I Read In 2019

Even if you don‚Äôt do the Guinness tour, there are a number of things around the brewery (and around the city) that will make fun, vibrant photos.

AND, Guinness has opened a new experimental brewpub taproom called Open Gate Brewery just a few minutes‚Äô walk from the storehouse. I‚Äôve heard it‚Äôs super cool but they weren‚Äôt open the last time I was there‚Ä¶they‚Äôre only open certain days so check the website ahead of time.

You might also like: 7 Travel Intentions for 2020

Take a tour of Jameson

I‚Äôd made a reservation at Jameson for a tour, and storm clouds were threatening and sprinkles had started as I made it to the distillery. I lucked out because it poured while I was in there, and didn‚Äôt rain on me the rest of the time. I hadn‚Äôt even brought a jacket on this trip (a day trip from out in the country), which was ballsy!

Jameson is the most well-known Irish whiskey in the world, and they offer tours at the location where they were founded in Dublin. It‚Äôs no longer a working distillery (they‚Äôve moved to much larger operations outside the city), but the tour is pretty decent and informational, and they do a nice job incorporating technology into the experience.

It‚Äôs about a 40-minute tour and then there‚Äôs a short tasting. You can hang out at the lovely bar area afterward if you‚Äôre inclined and order more interesting drinks. You can learn more about the tour, times, costs, etc. at the official website. Personally I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a must-do if you only have one or two days in Dublin, but is certainly fun.

Read my full post about visiting Jameson Distillery

You might also like: Travel FAQ: Things You Might Not Know About Your Credit Card

Or consider the smaller Teeling‚Äôs distillery

If Jameson feels too ‚Äúall the tourists do it‚Äù, then maybe you should pop in at Teeling‚Äôs instead. It is a smaller, more intimate tour experience, with knowledgeable guides and a cocktail at the end.

Teeling‚Äôs connection to Dublin dates back to the late 1700s, and this specific distillery is the first new one to open in Dublin in 125 years. Check tour times and prices here.

Kilmainham Gaol

I don‚Äôt have any pics of this, but if you‚Äôre open to something that‚Äôs rich in history (but admittedly a bit of a downer), Kilmainham Gaol has a ton to offer. Dating back to the late 1700s, it housed many Irish revolutionaries, including those who led the 1916 Easter Rising.

Many rebels and criminals (including children) were imprisoned and executed by the British for more than a century‚Ä¶I‚Äôm by no means an expert (especially since I haven‚Äôt had a chance to take the tour), so you can read up on some of the specifics here.

Splurge on a fancy afternoon tea

I didn‚Äôt get a chance to do this in Dublin, but have previously in London and at the gorgeous Dromoland Castle in western Ireland‚Äîand it‚Äôs an experience not to be missed!

Get a little dressed up and sip some fragrant tea (or go nuts and get champagne), eat your bodyweight in fluffy scones and jam, devour delicious sandwiches and pastries, and generally congratulate yourself on solid decision making.

A few of the best in Dublin are at The Shelbourne, The Merrion, and The Westbury. The pics below are from champagne afternoon tea at The Westbury, from my friend Andrea who highly recommends it!

If you‚Äôre traveling to Co Clare, try afternoon tea at Dromoland Castle!

Where to eat in Dublin

I haven‚Äôt spent more than a couple days here, so this is just a place to start. With 2 days in Dublin I‚Äôd recommend looking for a mixture of great traditional Irish and pub food, and finding some of the newer evolving Irish cuisine that‚Äôs put Dublin on the map for foodies.

My favorite stop on my most recent trip was Gallagher‚Äôs Boxty House, which I heard about from the Netflix show ‚ÄúSomebody Feed Phil‚Äú. I swung by their home in Temple Bar to see if it lived up to the hype. I had the boxty sampler platter, which includes dumplings (like gnocchi), bread, and fries. The fries were BOMB, and I could have eaten a couple orders of them alone.

I enjoyed one of their Jack Smyth stout beers with my snack, and later came back for a couple gin & tonics from their surprisingly interesting gin menu. Overall I totally recommend a stop here‚Äîdelish!

You might also like: Detailed Tips for the Best City Photography

One super interesting and delicious place to consider is Brother Hubbard. It came recommended from a couple places, including a work colleague and ‚ÄúSomebody Feed Phil‚Äú. It‚Äôs a great example of the interesting food scene that‚Äôs developed in Dublin, absolutely delicious food with a Middle Eastern/Mediterranean flair.

I started my morning here one day (though had already eaten breakfast so had to really stuff myself). I had a chocolate babka roll and Turkish eggs menemen topped with amazing whipped feta and olive yogurt, and was mad I couldn‚Äôt make myself eat more.

Another great breakfast or snack spot is the adorable Queen of Tarts bakery in Temple Bar. I fortified myself with a blueberry scone with jam and a cappuccino (the first of many!) before hitting the pavement on my first visit.

As you‚Äôre pounding the pavement, a stop at Murphy‚Äôs is a must. Originally from Dingle, they have a few shops sprinkled throughout Ireland, and their ice cream flavors are fascinating and awesome.

I had the Dingle sea salt as well as the brown bread. I‚Äôd totally recommend both. I‚Äôve heard there‚Äôs a Dingle gin flavor and was bummed it wasn‚Äôt on the menu when I visited‚Ä¶

But this is only the tip of the iceberg where the Dublin food scene is concerned. There‚Äôs tons of great traditional food, and a lot of fun pubs as well.

What are some less-known things to do with one or two days in Dublin that we missed? Let me know what to catch next time!

A Whirlwind Girls‚Äô Trip To San Juan, Puerto Rico: How to Plan The Best Itinerary

What To Do In Lisbon, Portugal: 20+ Awesome Sights & Experiences
